column2:
The pantheon of the Twelvegods is the most common and most influential religion in all of Aventuria, guiding spiritual life in almost the whole Middenrealm. It evolved out of a mixture of the gods and beliefs of settlers from the Gyldenland and native Aventurian peoples, particularly Tulamids. The pantheon in it's modern form was codified when, out of the chaos of the religious conflicts of the Dark Ages, emperor Silem-Horas decreed his famous edict named after himself in the year 98 before Bosparan's Fall. A pillar of support in all of life's hardships for the believer while acknowledging a great number of smaller cults as demigods allied to the true gods, the Twelve have been a force for good and peace throughout most of history. The twelve gods and their aspects are: 
 §MPraios§! – Alveran's sovereign, God of sun, law and nobility
 §MRondra§! – Goddess of battle and honour
 §MEfferd§! – God of the seas and storms
 §MTravia§! – Goddess of family, home and hospitality
 §MBoron§! – God of death, sleep and dreams
 §MHesinde§! – Goddess of science and magic
 §MFirun§! – God of winter and hunt
 §MTsa§! – Goddess of peace, birth and fertility
 §MPhex§! – God of luck, trade and thievery
 §MPeraine§! – Goddess of agriculture and medicine
 §MIngerimm§! – God of smithing and craftsmanship
 §MRahja§! – Goddess of love, wine and music

column2: While the religion of the Twelvegods recognizes the demigod Horas as the son of the celestial messenger Ucuri, the Church of Horas sees him as an envoy of all Twelve and arch-Alveranian, founder and patron saint of the Bosparanian – and later Horasian – Empire. Leading the empire himself for over 500 years before ascending to Alveran, Horas' name became the title of all emperors ruling in his place ever since.
column3: While the religion of the Twelvegods recognizes the demigod Horas as the son of Ucuri, the Church of Horas sees him as an envoy of all Twelve and arch-Alveranian, founder and patron saint of the Bosparanian – and later Horasian – Empire. column2: The Lowangian or Svelltvalian dualism is a sect popular in the former Svelltian city-league and parts of Andergast. The cult views Praios as the bringer of light, luck and as the embodiment of good while Boron, as the lord of darkness, represents evil. The rest of the Twelvegods pantheon is mostly ignored. The cult's priests urge their parish to diligence and a pure and chaste life.

column2: This radical cult of Praios is practised by the inhabitants of the island of Jilaskan. After Rohal the Wise ended the tyranny of the Priest-Kings in 466 after Bosparan's Fall, he banished the Praios priests to Jilaskan. Their descendants have continued their near-fanatical belief, isolated from the orders of the messenger of light, some would even say, the rest of the world.

column2: The principleists are a theological school in the Church of Praios, originally founded by Staryun Loriano in Vinsalt. Loriano and his supporters seek to return the church to it's principles that governed it in the old Bosparanian Empire. This includes a higher regard for Horas of course, but also a more tolerant approach to magic and those that wield it. While many are open to such a reform to the church in the parishes of Fairfield, believers in the Middenrealm usually view them as dangerous dissenters.

column2: Variations on the legend of Mada's crime against the Praios-given order of the world are known throughout Aventuria. Often she is recognized as a daughter of Hesinde, responsible for destroying the citadel of the element of magic, thus releasing it into the world where mortals abuse it to commit great sins. For her insurgence she was imprisoned in a stone in the sky, where Phex is tasked to watch over her. This is the reason the moon is most commonly known as Mada's Mark – but some, mainly Hesinde priests and witches, see her as a selfless liberator and seek to free her from her prison.

column2: When the soul raven Golgari, envoy of the god of death Boron, appeared amidst the chaos of a plague brought over the people of Al'Anfa by dying ravens in the year 686 after Bosparan's Fall, it caused a schism in the Church of Boron that endures to this day. Fearing for their lives, the people of Al'Anfa fled into the arms of the Nemekathean sect who try to divine Boron's will through dreams and intoxication and see ritualized suicide as a way of becoming one with Boron. These practices have split the two churches apart, leading to fierce battles with both words and steel.

column2: This cult of the god V'sar or Visar may seem like a cabalistic Boron cult to the uninitiated and is practised in the darker corners of Al'Anfa. This cult was originally practised by Achaz living south of the rain mountains but it has survived the ages and conquerors to influence a new people again and again. The façade of a more isolated Boron cult quickly falls under scrutiny and reveals a much more bloody cult of the lord of perfect souls, V'sar. The cold-blooded disregard for life it's believers have mirrors not just the inhuman nature of the Achaz but also the bloody sacrifice of the Wudu people who inherited the cult from them.

column2: Believers of Kor, lord of nine deadly strikes and son of Rondra and high dragon Famerlor, can be found all over Aventuria. The cult's most imporant temples are located in South Aventuria. Wherever mercenaries gather you are bound to find at least a few worshipping the god of pugnacity, loyalty and the good fight, although he is popular among adventurers as well. While Kor and his believers are often suspicious or even terrifying to people due to their ruthlessness and the manticore they fly on their banners, faithfuls are keen to argue against any supposed demonic nature of their god. After all, sacrifices can sate Kor's bloodlust just as well and his priests would never attack those unwilling to fight.

column2: While the most important temple of the Church of Nandus is in Vinsalt, his priests don't regard hierarchy very highly. Therefore Nandus priests can often be found wandering throughout Aventuria, collecting new insights very similar to those ordained to Hesinde, Nandus' mother. However, where Hesinde seeks to collect knowledge, Nandus wishes to teach it to all willing. This often brings them in conflict with the priests of Praios (and nobility) who question a farmer's need for literacy and numeracy as long as they know their rightful place in the world. Disciples of Nandus are not overly altruistic however, should a learner prove too ignorant for their wisdom they will quickly move on to the next. The priests hope to do their part in furthering all of humanities' knowledge, so mortals will one day achieve unification with Nayrakis, the essence of Los and cosmological force of order.

column2: While the only official temple of the god of virility and animalistic strength is located in Fasar, many clearings, woods and groves all over Aventuria are said to be places of worship for Levthan. The son of Rahja was, according to legend, desired by all women he set eyes upon, except for Satuaria who taunted him. So one night, Levthan subdued her with the help of an enchanted tie given to him by Hesinde and conquered Satuaria. But she took her revenge on him when she turned Levthan into a common ram, cursed to spend his days on a dry meadow, feeding of fierce herbs. It is said Satuaria later often rued her curse for she was filled equally with love and hate for her conqueror. But every once in a while Levthan manages to shake off his curse for a night, spending it in a wild ecstatic round dance with those devoted to Satuaria. Some suggest Levthan has long abandoned everything holy and is now a follower of Rahja's wicked adversary Belkelel. Levthan's horns, reminiscent of the demonic beings of the 7th sphere have only strengthened these suspicions.

column2: The religion of the godwhale Swafnir is connected to the Twelvegods pantheon and is commonly practised in the northwest of Aventuria. While known as the son of proud Rondra and capricious Efferds to most people, the Thorwalians have made him their tutelary deity when he reveald himself to their ancestors under the leadership of Jurga Tjalfsdottir and saved them from drowning on the crossing to Aventuria from the Gyldenland. Similar to the society of Thorwal, the church is only loosely structured, placing an emphasis on personal freedom and tending to those blessed with Swafskari, the whale rage that marks individuals as chosen by Swafnir.

column2: The people of the city of Waskir, Thorwalian stronghold on the edge of the Orkland, are surrounded by a unique blend of religions that evolved out of the city's turbulent history. Besides the Twelvegods brought to the city by Bosparanian fugitives after the fall of the empire and the Swafnir belief found in all of Thorwal, the Waskirians pray to a wealth of demigods, saints, spirits and mythical creatures. Among these, Kor will be best known to the unsuspecting traveller while the belief in the Orkish god Razorag may shock and anger some visitors. The cult of the Sons of the Storm however, or prayers to the Thorwalian hero Torstor Om will just leave most people unfamiliar with local customs incredulous. Nevertheless, the Thorwalian spirit of freedom is strong in the people of Waskir and they will defend their hodgepodge of gods should the need arise.

column2: The belief in Rastullah is a monotheistic religion usually found in and around the desert Khôm. After Rastullah had created Ethra and all the beings living on it and even time itself, he rested for 7 days – an eon in human time. When he awoke, he found that only one people had remained true to him, the tribe of the Beni Novad. He revealed himself to them in the oasis of Keft in the year 760 after Bosparan's Fall and gave them 99 laws so that they would not stray from their path. While many of these laws are ambiguous enough to provoke long and heated discussions between two Rastullah believers, they are united in their fight against the damnable god lizard.

column2: The Beni Kasim, or Kasimites, are a tribe of Novadi known for their fanatical and fundamentalist Rastullah belief, populating the area between Wal-el-Khômchra and the Western Khoram mountains. For the Kasimites, even the strict school of Unau is too lenient on the Rastullah believer, leading to disputes even with other believers born in the desert Khôm, not to mention their ruthlessness with which they meet infidels. Nevertheless their influence on the Mawdlis of the Caliphate is immense  and they are often praised as the most devout of all of Rastullah's followers.

column2: In some areas of the lands of the Tulamids the beliefs of times long past have survived Satinav's horns. Often remote and not of interest to zealous realms such as the Caliphate, people still pray to the Twelvegods the way they have since they adapted the belief from the Bosparanian empire. Under the watchful eye of Feqz, god of magic and enemy to all lizards, the pantheon includes gods familiar to Middenrealmians such as Praios or Rascha, mixed with demigods like Marhibo and rounded off with gods unknown to most nowadays, such as Tuur-Mhakaq, Al'Mahmoud or Gadanga.
column3: In some areas of the lands of the Tulamids the beliefs of times long past have survived Satinav's horns. Often remote and not of interest to zealous realms such as the Caliphate, people still pray to the Twelvegods the way they have since they adapted the belief from the Bosparanian empire. Under the watchful eye of Feqz, god of magic and enemy to all lizards, the pantheon includes gods familiar to Middenrealmians such as Praios or Rascha, mixed with demigods like Marhibo and rounded off with gods unknown to most nowadays, such as Tuur-Mhakaq, Al'Mahmoud or Gadanga.
column4: In some areas of the lands of the Tulamids the beliefs of times long past have survived Satinav's horns. Often remote and not of interest to zealous realms such as the Caliphate, people still pray to the Twelvegods the way they have since they adapted the belief from the Bosparanian empire. Under the watchful eye of Feqz, god of magic and enemy to all lizards, the pantheon includes gods familiar to Middenrealmians such as Praios or Rascha, mixed with demigods like Marhibo and rounded off with gods unknown to most nowadays, such as Tuur-Mhakaq, Al'Mahmoud or Gadanga.

column2: The cult of the Uled ash'Shebah (Seed of the Throne) often operates similar to a secret society across the desert Khôm and Almada and preaches the worship of the old dragons, particularly Pyrdacor and Umbracor. The cult evolved from remains of the mythical Dragonorder, which held vast lands during the Dark Age and penned the legendary Draconomicon. While many of the order's secrets went down with it, the Uled ash'Shebah saved some of them and now try to trace the location of many of the orders artifacts. Meanwhile, the promises of power and wealth held by ancient secrets and dragon spells ensure the cult finds new patrons and believers.

column2: The Beni Uchakâni (Sons of the mountain lion) are a Hadjin order that pray to the god lion Ra'Andra. Located in the Khoram mountains, the honour code of the Beni Uchakâni is among the strictest of all Hadjinim, demanding abstinence from all worldly pleasures.
column3: The Beni Uchakâni (Sons of the mountain lion) are a Hadjin order that pray to the god lion Ra'Andra. Located in the Khoram mountains, the honour code of the Beni Uchakâni is among the strictest of all Hadjinim, demanding abstinence from all worldly pleasures.

column2: The cult of the twins Rur & Gror is the predominant religion of the island Maraskan. As the holy scrolls of the Beni Rurech tell us, the world was created eons ago by brothersister Rur to give as a gift to brothersister Gror, with all of Ethra's inhabitants living out multiple cycles of life, death and reincarnation on it's voyage from one to the other. The Twelvegods then are guardian spirits, tasked by Rur to protect the disk and it's wonders. The dual nature of the celestial twins has inspired their believers to look for balance in numbers in every aspect of their daily life, from the coins in their pockets to their number of descendants.

column2: Holy Scrolls of the Beni Rurech

column2: The young sect of the judges exists mainly among the Maraskanian diaspora. Originating from the New Jergan quarter in Festum, the sect sees itself as the revived version of a sect from the priest kings age carrying the same name. Preaching the strict and abstemious worship of Praios and Phex as a singular entity, judges of day and night, the cult manages to clash heads with many priests of the Twelvegods while also steadily rising in popularity among the otherwise very relaxed and hedonistic displaced Maraskani. They seek to bring justice back to Maraskan and since one of their mottos is „The truthful one is full of cunning“ they have been more successful than most.

column2: The sect Garasabayad Mercy was founded in the 8th century after Bosparan's Fall. Since the Golden-Winged One, known to other religions as the Nameless One, must be a creation of Rur & Gror as well, they preach that once every human life he gets the chance to repent for his sins and swear off the ethrajin. Needless to say most other religions either think them naïve or dangerous.

column2: The religion of the Celestial Wolves is found in North Aventuria where it is practiced by the tribes of Nivese.  Since Vaë's son Mada brought sin over mankind when he struck dead Liskas puppies, a tribe's kaskju must make sure the tribe does not anger the Celestial Wolves and pays tribute to any wolf packs they encounter on their nomadic journeys. Should they fail the Celestial Wolves under the leadership of the fierce Gorfang may devastate the land, as they once did after Mada's crime.

column2: Some tribes of the Nivese in the south west of the Grimfrost Wastes pray to the frostworm Schirr'Zach as the chronicler of world. The feared dragon is over 4000 years old and was originally created by the god dragon Pyrdacor as the first of his species. Shirr'Zach is a brilliant ice molder and collects ice statues in his treasure hoard. - some say they look eerily realistic...

column2: The cult of the white mammoth Natûru-Gon is found in the cold north west of Aventuria. The Gjalskerlanders pray to Natûru-Gon and his children, the Brenna-Gon, for protection of their families, fertility and prowess in battle. His nemesis, the merciless Zwanfir who wants to drown the world in his icy ocean realm, is often the cause for bloody battles with Thorwalians. However, true evil is known to the Brenoch-Dûn as Calyach'an Mochûla, the mother of demons. To purge the world of such evil, the Brenoch-Dûn have learned to channel the spirit, the odûn, of mighty animals.

column2: The haerad of the Skoth'sloch (shadow bog) was a tribe of Gjalskerlanders living close to the Brinask Marshes that worshipped demons. Though much of what happened to the haerad is lost to the fog of time, some say the tribe's Brenoch-Dûn spent too much of his time in the spirit world, returning with a clouded mind. He convinced the haerad to discard their old gods and turn to the Mochûla instead, which lead to their downfall. Most believe only their Molû-Parra-Dûn remain, the tainted spirit of their corrupted souls.

column2: The belief in Frunu and Angara can be found in the far north of Aventuria among the Frundengar (Those protected by Frunu), a people often called Fjarningians elsewhere. The skuldar of the Frundengar do not pray to the gods for they would not listen to such maudlin begging. Deeds are all that count for the grim god of ice and hunting. Only his hot-blooded wife Angara may melt his heart, which is the source of summer. Instead, the skuldar function as teachers, judges and keepers of tradition and legend. Among them are the legends that warn of Swafnir the Jealous and Hramaschtu, Frunus dark brother and competitor for Angara's love.

column2: Frundengar tribes in the Northern Misty Peaks worship the winter dragon Karankarn. Seeing him as a viceregent of their gods Frunu and Angara, they often offer the dragon prayer and oblations – some say they include human sacrifices.
column3: Frundengar tribes in the Northern Misty Peaks worship the winter dragon Karankarn. Seeing him as a viceregent of their gods Frunu and Angara, they often offer the dragon prayer and oblations – some say they include human sacrifices.

column2: Deep in the impassable jungles of South Aventuria, the forest men commonly called Moha worship the celestial jaguar Kamaluq as their creator. Kamaluq created the forest men to save the world he created, the jungle, from pale intruders chopping it down and building dead cities of stone in it's place. Luckily, the shamans of the forest men can use the power of the Nipakau, the spirits of nature, to beat back these tapam-less intruders.

column2: Near the city of Mirham, Anoiha tribes worship the giant lindworm Ykkandil. The cunning dragon is over 1.800 years old and is slowly expanding his circle of faithfuls. Upon their coming of age, the tribes under Ykkandil's control send their young men to him to prove themselves worthy. Should the dragon find them loyal to him, they return a respected member of their tribe, otherwise they are never seen again. Similarly, escaped slaves that wish to join the tribe are usually sent to see the dragon – few return.

column2: Most tribes of the Utulu tell legends that long ago, they lived in Obaran's empire of the sun. But due to the paradisical nature of their ancestor's lands they grew careless, which allowed the Nightblack Mistress, ruler of the dark sea, to pull the Utulu down into her dark realm. Once their ancestors managed to flee, they realized they could not face Obaran again and so, in shame, they turned their backs on his empire and fled across the sea to Aventuria.

column2: The cult of Raschtula and Rascha is found among the Ferkina tribes of Aventuria, most often along the mountains surrounding the desert Khôm. While the gods are powerful, they are not inherently good or bad. Therefore, they represent the give and take of life, life and death, violence and lust. Raschtula, god of violence and power, lord of sun and death incites battle and war wherever he roams and finds particular enjoyment in the wrothful and those quick to lose their temper. Rascha, his wife, is the goddess of wild lust and fury that is honoured by debaucherous orgies. This wild and ruthless belief leads to the Ferkina looking down on those that call themselves civilized. These Bloodless are only good for robbing, killing or kidnapping at best.
